post_title: Do you check for bedbugs when you get to a new hotel?

comments.author: elementaldelirium
comments.body: I check every hotel and air bnb. I just lift the sheets and use a flashlight. They can be very expensive and hard to get rid of, so I’d prefer to avoid bringing them back if at all possible.

comments.author: brokeneckblues
comments.body: Doesn’t matter how nice a place is. First thing I do I lift all the bedding and check for those little fuckers.

comments.author: byronite
comments.body: Check mattress on arrival and **also check your sheets on departure.**  If your hotel has bugs they will probably show spots on the sheets after a night or two.  That way you can take precautions to avoid bringing them home.

comments.author: thehotflashpacker
comments.body: Also, put your luggage on a hard surface (some people even will store it in the bathtub, but my preference is the luggage rack, separated from the wall a little bit).  Never store it on the floor or next to the bed.  The little buggers will crawl in and then you take them home.

comments.author: Fernweh_vagabond
comments.body: Omg yes I check every time. Hotel, Airbnb, glamping, doesn’t matter. I check. Every. Time. A bed bug run-in at a hotel in 2015 has me traumatized for life. I don’t use a hairdryer or iron, I use a flashlight and lift every mattress and check the headboards and behind the night tables and headboard if you can see back there.

comments.author: LeadingPatience3183
comments.body: Yep, got to an airbnb spent a few hours on the couch before going to bed. Went to lay in the bed but noticed some things crawling on the side of the bed... full blown bed bugs on a highly rated property. The owner said I brought them in... I never touched the bed

comments.author: throwaybeauty
comments.body: Yes absolutely. We got bed bugs a few years ago and it took six months of steam cleaning our couch and bed (mattress and frame - since the frame is fabric) consistently (daily then weekly) to finally get rid of them. Never again. I check the mattress, and everything gets bagged and washed/dried immediately upon returning home.

comments.author: spinonesarethebest
comments.body:
Bedbugs fluoresce under UV light.  I put my stuff in the tub, turn off all the lights, and check bedding and upholstery.
Light is small and was $15 at AutoZone.

comments.author: Apollyon314
comments.body: Hell yes

comments.author: talldean
comments.body:
I travel 90 days a year, have for years, and have both never checked and also never had a problem.

I'm sure it hits every hotel, and most hotels see this issue about once or twice a year.

comments.author: Intrepid_Brother2660
comments.body: Is anyone else feeling itchy ever since reading this post?

comments.author: flyingcircusdog
comments.body: Lift all the sheets and check any crevices on the mattress for bugs or black specs.

comments.author: gunbuster363
comments.body:
Never did. Have never thought about it and most of the time I was too tired.

I have eradicated bed bugs from my apartment twice. Yes I know about them.

comments.author: TideRoll41
comments.body:
After the Reddit algorithm hooked me here, I started checked every hotel room. 

Suitcase and bag outside in the hall, I walk in with phone, and inspect the corners of the mattress. If all is good, quick check of the dresser and sofa (if applicable) and then bring stuff inside.

comments.author: lavenderghostt
comments.body: I always check now after an incident where I woke up in the middle of the night from being bit by something at a hotel, and ended up finding bed bugs in the bed. I’d rather know.

comments.author: sucobe
comments.body: Never checked. Never any issues.

comments.author: mbarker1012
comments.body: Never not once lol. And never noticed any issues.

comments.author: mutemarmot42
comments.body: Yep. Check the bed, furniture, carpet, rugs, anything fabric/upholstered with a flashlight before I open my suitcase or even sit down. My dad brought them home once, it costs a pretty penny to get rid of those little bastards.

comments.author: CormoranNeoTropical
comments.body:
I had a horrible experience with bedbugs once: hundreds of bites all over my body, had to throw away my suitcase. 

But I’ve never checked for them before or since.

comments.author: ODB247
comments.body: Yes I always check the room before I bring anything in or put any items down. It's not just bedbugs, it's roaches and fleas as well. I also look up the address on the bedbug registry website and check Yelp and Google reviews before I book.

comments.author: NArcadia11
comments.body: Nope. I’ve stayed in a thousand hotel rooms and only got bedbugs once from the nastiest hostel in Rome lol

comments.author: jockosrocket
comments.body: Yes I always check. I also clean the TV remote with disinfectant wipes.

comments.author: maulsma
comments.body: I’ve never checked for them in the soft furnishings, but I check the Bedbug Registry on line before booking anywhere.  After watching a video of someone checking a bed with an iron I’ve thought I might try  it.

comments.author: Xerisca
comments.body:
My spouse used to work at a hotel, a NICE hotel at that. He's absolutely religious about checking after seeing the nightmare bedbugs can cause, and they can pop up in the nicest, cleanest hotels. He's also 100% obsessed with never allowing our luggage to be put anywhere but on a shelf, table, desk, or counter. Never do our bags or clothing get put on beds or floors. Bed bugs can't really climb smooth surfaces, so most tables and counters are pretty safe. 

So, the answer is a hard yes, we check. That also includes checking plane seats and train beds and seats when possible.

comments.author: BeiHall
comments.body:
Bedbugs are horrible. They really mess with your mental health. 

I had one long bout with them (our building in NYC had them.) Ruined my relationship, my mental state, my finances. After months of fumigating, got rid of them, then moved out and bought everything new. 

Then, 3 years later, I was backpacking for months through Europe. I arrived exhausted, late at night, to a hostal in Bilbao.  The only place with vacancy. I noticed one climbing up a wall, killed it, fresh blood. I was horrified. I saw another on a different wall. I was horrified, but had nowhere else to go. So I did the only sensible thing. 

I carefully hung my bag off of a wall (nothing had come in contact yet. Basically said to myself “I have nowhere to go at this hour, I need to sleep. I will offer myself to these for tonight, then trash all of these clothes and change into safe ones.”

You want to avoid them, so yes, I check hotel rooms…. They really screw with you.

comments.author: Finemind
comments.body: Always! I've never found any, but always check!

comments.author: CraftFamiliar5243
comments.body: I have a friend whose husband traveled all over the world. His suitcase didn't leave the laundry room. His clothes went directly to the washer or cleaners after each trip. His suitcase wasn't allowed out of the laundry room.

comments.author: Aero136
comments.body: Yes. Every. Single. Time. It doesn't matter where I stay or what type of accommodation. I have found bed bugs at an upscale resort on Kauai that I never would've expected along with in first class seats on an airplane.

comments.author: Sensitive-Rip-8005
comments.body: The minute I walk in. I used to do a lot of traveling for work and woke up at home one morning to discover them. I spoke to the pest control guy about what he does when he travels. Besides the usual of putting the luggage in the tub, never on the floor or bed, and inspecting. One thing he does is always ask when checking in what their policy is when bed bugs are reported. This lets them know you’ll be doing a thorough check and will likely not check you into a room or one close by that was previously reported as having them.

comments.author: katmndoo
comments.body: DIdn't used to, but... Got 'em once, and I'm pretty sure I know the hotel they came from.

comments.author: Travel_Frick
comments.body: I have been a business traveler for 24 years and never once have I looked for bed bugs, used a UV light or sprayed disinfectant on anything. Short of leaving the hotel if you ask for another room more than likely the same person that cleaned your room cleaned the one they want to move you to.

comments.author: Excellent-Throat5582
comments.body: Always. It doesn’t take long at all.

comments.author: Putasonder
comments.body: Yes. I pull the sheets and blankets back from the foot of the bed and look for any signs.

comments.author: UTFTCOYB_Hibboriot
comments.body: Nah!  They’re hiding anyway!! Waiting for the succulent legs

comments.author: Historical-Ad-146
comments.body: I only check if a hotel feels like maybe it wasn't the best choice. Never actually found any.

comments.author: Conscious_Valuable90
comments.body: Yes. I have glue traps and pocket heat things that I put by the headboard or mattress near the head board.

comments.author: Low_Atmosphere2982
comments.body:
I do. When I first get into a room, my bags and everything go straight into the bathroom. I put them in the tub or the shower. I get out my flashlight, it has a regular light and a UV setting. They glow under UV light. I check the bed, strip the sheets and lift the mattress, check the headboard and all around the room.

I also make sure that my bags never touch any fabric or carpet in the room. I bring hooks with me and either hang them in the closet or hang them over the top of a door. If I need to get something out of them, they go on the counter in the bathroom or on a desk top. I keep my shoes in the bathroom as well, either on the back of the toilet or on a shelf for counter.

Bedbugs are also attracted to dirty clothes so I have a separate laundry bag that I hang up in the bathroom and all my dirty clothes go in there. Before I pack them back in my bag, I put them in one of those Ziploc rollable vacuum bags, vacuum pack them , and then put them in my bag.

When I get home, my bags go in the guest bathtub along with my shoes. I strip out of my clothing and toss my clothes and the clothes out of my bag directly in the washing machine. I take a shower and put clean clothes on from my house. 

I'll usually leave my bags in the tub for a couple days just to see if I see anything crawling out of them

I had a neighbor who got bedbugs and it cost them like $15,000 out of pocket to get them treated.

comments.author: StanUrbanBikeRider
comments.body: Yes

comments.author: Nancebythelake
comments.body: You should definitely check and hopefully there’s nothing going on. But if you see little tiny bugs that are dark rust color that’s a problem.

comments.author: sykokiller11
comments.body: I never used to.  I went on a trip with my cousin who travels constantly.  Every place we stayed he had us leave our luggage outside while he lifted sheets and mattresses with a flashlight in his hand.  After hearing his story and reading some here I do the same now.  I’ve never seen a bedbug in person and hope it stays that way!

comments.author: Mr_Lumbergh
comments.body: Every time, even if it’s just lifting the sheets checking for blood stains.

comments.author: Mom2askater
comments.body: Nope.

comments.author: Strong-Landscape7492
comments.body: Never checked, never had issues.

comments.author: Longjumping_Set_754
comments.body: Always always always

comments.author: Maure_a_Ottawa
comments.body: Yes, always, and before unpacking.

comments.author: BrandonBollingers
comments.body: Whenever I remember to yes. Had bedbugs in college…hell. Never again.

comments.author: CharmingWarlord
comments.body: I always do. We stayed in a place earlier this year in Ohio that had them. We did Check the bed and didn’t see anything suspicious but we were covered in bites. We ended up moving rooms after the second night and taking everything to a laundromat and cooking out clothes in the dryer. We kept our bags outside in black trash bags in the sun for a month. Luckily we did not infest our home.

comments.author: bunneetoo
comments.body: Check. Used to travel a lot for work and found them more than once. The hotel moved me immediately and helped me check the new room (get a different floor on the other side of the building if possible). It takes a minute but totally worth not bringing bedbugs home.

comments.author: Accomplished-Bug4327
comments.body:
Yessss- I lift the sheets and look at the mattress. Like everyone else has said the reason to be so diligent about avoiding them is the huge expense and hassle of getting rid of them. 

I worked at a hotel (Rodeway Inn, Bozeman, Montana) for a semester in college and there was one room that had bed bugs. The hotel knew about it and even they couldn’t get rid of the bugs. We were told to never rent that room out… except for when the hotel was full. So yeah definitely good to always check- they’re out there

comments.author: alibythesea
comments.body:
I check online, search reviews on Google and Booking, and keep my carryon/knapsack on the luggage rack. I occasionally do a bed check if the room feels less than pristine. 

I’ve only been bitten once, in a particularly downmarket Motel 8 or Super 6 (last room in town, as we didn’t know there was a Judas Priest concert in Bangor ME that night, and really didn’t think everything would be sold out in Maine in April …). As soon as I got home the suitcase went into a large contractor’s bag in the chest freezer, the clothes went through the washer twice, and then hung in the sun for several days. I escaped any house contamination, thank god.

comments.author: pocahantaswarren
comments.body:
Let me tell you, I had bedbugs once in my apartment due to them coming through the wall between me and my neighbor. They crawled through the wall outlets. Most stressful and traumatizing 6 months of my life.

These days I check every time I travel. I’ve yet to find any, but did have a false alarm in NYC. Thought I found some droppings so I requested a room change and they upgraded us to a full bedroom suite that would’ve cost double. They emailed me later and said it had been examined and cleared by the exterminator. But yeah I’m not taking any chances.

comments.author: Neat-Cry5648
comments.body: Yes I do now after getting horrible bed bug bites in a moderately priced hotel! I had such a horrible reaction to them, it took two urgent care trips and two rounds of steroids to get rid of the reaction. I had them all over my face, arms and legs. Each of the bites swelled up to nickel sized welts. I also had to treat every crevice of my home and furniture as I feared i had transported them home in my luggage. I now check meticulously at every hotel and air bnb.

comments.author: jumbocards
comments.body: I take my chances at 4/5 star hotels only.  I also never had bed bug issue since college.  Maybe I am lucky in this regard.  I do travel about 100 days a year.

comments.author: elsie78
comments.body: Every time, even if I've stayed there before.

comments.author: Regalgarnion
comments.body: Immediately

comments.author: TheBlueManatee
comments.body: Yes

comments.author: Ok-Aardvark-2106
comments.body: I didn’t use to up until recently, when I got bit by an ant. Lesson learned and from now on I know to check every time

comments.author: zoobilyzoo
comments.body: I only encountered bedbugs once in my life. I speak as someone who travels all the time.

comments.author: ElenaDellaLuna
comments.body: Always. Every time.

comments.author: evenfallframework
comments.body: Every. Single. Time. All four corners of the mattress, and all soft chairs/furniture.

comments.author: Mushrooming247
comments.body: Yes, sounds like you’ve lucked out so far, but I check every time. Just glance around, and go back down to the front desk to request a new room if you see them, it just takes a few minutes more and can alleviate an expensive and time-consuming hassle.

comments.author: badlcuk
comments.body: I check everywhere i stay, although I'm sure I'm not that good, and I am always petrified to find anything. I'm not sure what you mean by iron, i just use my eyes and a flashlight. Fortunately I've never seen any bug issues (i've seen other things, but tried to put that out of my head) so I've been happy about that.

comments.author: reikalykos
comments.body: Every single time

comments.author: CenlaLowell
comments.body: Every time and I keep my suitcase on the outside the door or I pick them up and put them on top of the table until we make sure everything is good

comments.author: EntranceOld9706
comments.body:
I don’t check, and I travel about that much for work too.

Maybe I’m flippant about this. I’ve only had bedbugs as an actual issue once — at a Ramada Inn in west Memphis, Arkansas 🥲

comments.author: gertrude32
comments.body:
Yes! My grandmas house had them. (We think  they hitched a ride after she was in a nursing home rehab). It took multiple heat treatments and chemicals to get rid of those fuckers. My mom was her caretaker at the time…they ended up spreading to her house too!  So yes!!! Always check and wash everything when you get home immediately. I even leave my suitcase in the garage for a whole
Afterwards.

comments.author: notassigned2023
comments.body: I always look but perhaps not too thoroughly and my eyesight isn’t what it used to be.  Doubt I’d find tiny ones and maybe not spots, but def a big infestation.

comments.author: ducksx10
comments.body: I usually don't check but I think I should start.

comments.author: OutsideAspect7298
comments.body: One of my coworkers checked into a room with bed bugs from a very reputable hotel. I’ve been checking my rooms ever since.  Even after I check I don’t lay anything on the ground or the bed. I only unpack what I need for the day and my luggage stays shut the rest of the time.

comments.author: nr5nr5
comments.body: No

comments.author: MinimumIndependence9
comments.body: Yes, I always check. We brought them home from a hotel once and had to pay for an exterminator. We caught it early, and it was still thousands of dollars to get rid of them. I always check now. When I get home, all clothes in the suitcase go in the dryer for 60 mins to kill anything we might have brought home- advice from the exterminator.

comments.author: Audi_R8_97
comments.body: It's the first thing I do when I get to my room. I've never gotten any before but it doesn't hurt to check to make sure you don't bring any home.

comments.author: Salt-Crazy113
comments.body: 100% I do! The nightmare of bedbugs is something I don’t want to ever go through.

comments.author: LivingArrival88
comments.body:
I had them twice in a hotel room, but I only noticed once I already checked out. I stayed at a different hotel the night after and started feeling itchy. Reached out to both hotels. The hotel I was currently staying did the right thing and checked everything and even sent me a pest control report which was negative. The first hotel was trying to lie to me and after back and forth turned out they had an incident in that room a week prior.

Thankfully I did not bring them home as I was taking all the right steps. Here is what I do since this happened:

I usually don’t check the mattress (they can also hide in the frame or any other small cracks. I pay close attention to the sheets. I never throw or put clothes on the bed. I travel with a hardshell suitcase I always close after use and I always store it at the luggage rack or the bathtub.

comments.author: magenta-hello
comments.body: YES. Lift the corners, even the mattress cover. Look for blood spots and scurrying bugs. If I have alcohol with me I spray it as it makes them scatter.

comments.author: EggStrict8445
comments.body: I wouldn’t know if I saw one. All the energy spent worrying about it would probably ruin my stay, so no.

comments.author: RoughPlum6669
comments.body: Holy @&$!, yes I check! And I briefly search hotel reviews from recent guests - I type in “bedbug” or “bites” in reviews on google or whatever before I book.

comments.author: Ophiocordycepsis
comments.body: I do in poorly maintained (funky-smelling) hotels, rental houses, and in tropical countries. Just a peek under the sheets for the brown spots. I usually don’t bother at a Hilton or Marriott etc in the U.S.

comments.author: SnarkingOverNarcing
comments.body: Only if something else about the hotel has raised a big red flag, otherwise I’m not in the mood/financial bracket to keep booking new hotel rooms

comments.author: Grouchy-Traveller
comments.body: Traveling full time , and yes, beds are checked. One thing to be very careful with is never to put your suitcase, backpack, or clothes on the bed; keep it as far away from the bed on a desk or chair with no cushion . If something has touched the bed, it shouldn’t go back in your suitcase or backpack to avoid bringing back unwanted little friends.

comments.author: good_enuffs
comments.body: I always check and I have run into them and left the hotel.

comments.author: wino12312
comments.body: Yep. Every time. Every where

comments.author: Busted_Toad
comments.body: Every bed, every time!

comments.author: Carolinagirl9311
comments.body: Always!!!

comments.author: Terrible-Opinion-888
comments.body: always

comments.author: harmlessgrey
comments.body: It's the first thing my husband does when we get to a hotel or Airbnb.

comments.author: Allsugaredup2024
comments.body: Every time. I also leave all of my items except for toiletries in my own suitcase. I don't unpack anything because it's a waste since I'm just going to have to repack it again anyway.

comments.author: mb303666
comments.body: No!

comments.author: springsomnia
comments.body: Always.

comments.author: Empath1999
comments.body: I always do

comments.author: PeterMus
comments.body:
Not using the dresser/storage provided other than the closet can help reduce your risk of getting bedbugs quite a bit.

I've started hanging my clothes and keeping other items in my suitcase.

comments.author: MarvelousTravels
comments.body: The second I get home I “cook” my bags

comments.author: crazymastiff
comments.body: Every single time

comments.author: fiddle1fig
comments.body: Always

comments.author: Typical_Ad_7291
comments.body: Yes

comments.author: magicalfolk
comments.body:
💯 always 
I actually don’t bring my luggage up till I’ve properly checked the room,  once im satisfied I’ll go down and let them know if anything is missing or want to change the room or it’s perfect. It gives me peace of mind and staff are aware that I’m not going to let unhygienic stuff slide.  
I always tip the cleaning staff each morning and a smiley note that’s says Thank you : ) 
It’s worked so far!  🤞

comments.author: nonnymauss
comments.body: Every time. I lift a corner of the sheet at the head of the bed and look at the mattress using the flashlight on my phone. And check around the headboard.

comments.author: Unsteady_Tempo
comments.body:
Yes. 100% of the time. 

I peel back all of the sheets down the bare mattress on two corners of each bed.  I inspect the seams and lift the mattress to look between it and the box spring.  I then look over any chairs or sofas as well as open all of the drawers.   I use a flashlight to look behind the headboard (if possible) and any furniture.

comments.author: Mitaslaksit
comments.body:
Hell yeah! It is our responsibility to not spread them.

I usually book a heat treatment for my luggage upon arrival back home. I drive there directly from the airport and leave all my belongings to be heated.
This gives me such a peace of mind.

comments.author: mandicapped
comments.body: I have delt with the scourge before! I don't do a check, but I am on guard. BB have a very distinctive smell, so if I start getting itchy, or notice black spots, I go on the hunt for them!

comments.author: kaylalancaster
comments.body: After staying in an Air BnB that had bedbugs, I will be checking every hotel/Air BnB I stay in going forward

comments.author: DrCrazyFishMan1
comments.body: Life is too short for that

comments.author: questdragon47
comments.body:
Don’t forget to check other places too! 

My friend went to a hotel and did the bed check and thought she was good to go. There were bed bugs in the couch.

comments.author: realmozzarella22
comments.body: We encountered them on a trip about 10 years ago.  So we do check.  A short review of the bedding is usually enough.

comments.author: PhiL0Ma7h
comments.body:
My wife checks everywhere

I used to think it was excessive, then we got em in our apartment complex by someone’s wash not being thoroughly cleaned with hot water

Now I don’t blame her

comments.author: MoxxFulder
comments.body:
Every time.  Peel back the covers and check the “piping” on the mattress, this is where you would usually find them.  If you find them, leave the room asap and don’t stay in the hotel.  Had coworkers who had to spend thousands to eradicate them after they hitched a ride back home in luggage.  

I would also recommend avoid any teapot or coffee pot in room, they tend to skip cleaning these thoroughly, and I’ve seen things growing in them occasionally.  Be wary of any glassware in room as many hotels have been known to cut corners, ie windex and a rag to “clean” a glass before returning it to the minibar.

comments.author: Llewellyn90
comments.body: Yes every time

comments.author: NoiseyTurbulence
comments.body:
Yes, I absolutely do. I stayed at a place in Sacramento once before and woke up the next morning with bedbug bites all down my neck and I had a rash for weeks after, it was horrible.

Ever since, I always check my room everywhere I stay.

comments.author: littlemybb
comments.body: I used to not until a hotel I stayed at had a bedbug scare. I didn’t get them, but it freaked me out so bad.

comments.author: tjlawless911
comments.body: They lives everywhere. I had them a few years ago. Nearly drove me mad. I had to ove, and leave all my furniture behind. All of it. Bed is a euphemism. They can live in your coffee table. They live in your baseboards. They infest your electrical outlets. They're awful. One of the most horrifying experiences of my life, and I've had some bad experiences.

comments.author: harperfin
comments.body:
Traveling in Morocco, I opened a paperback book I'd left on the nightstand in a nice hotel to find several crawling inside the pages. I quickly squashed them. I presumed I'd carried them from the last hotel, which was kind of seedy. 
When I returned home to the US, it was below freezing and I left my luggage with all its contents outside in my yard for several days, then washed everything in hot water. But then the psychological torture started.
Every night I'd feel things crawling on me - would sit up and turn on the lights and find nothing. I'd find a tiny itchy spot on my skin and the anxiety would escalate. I was obsessively checking all my furniture and clothing, and couldn't stop reading bedbug horror stories online. 
It took several months to feel normal again and sleep through the night without that crawly feeling.
I'm not sure my mental health could survive an actual infestation and I always check hotel rooms - around the mattress, cracks and crevices of any furniture and behind the headboard if possible. Luggage up off the floor and bed. And I wash all clothes in hot water the minute I get home.

comments.author: zennie4
comments.body:
100-150 days travelling yearly for past 10 years (excluding covid years). 

I only checked maybe 5 times altogether when the room or bed looked shady. 

Got bit by bedbugs twice, not nice but far worse thing happened to me so far. I'm definitely too lazy to waste time checking the room every time I move, usually I'm happy just to finally relax when I check in. 

The two times were where I wouldn't expect it really, first one was a hostel in my own country's capital in Europe (needed a quick crash after a work party) and second one way a very nice hotel in Vietnam I had stayed before a few times without any issues. 

I'm surprised how many people say they put their bag in a bathtub etc.

comments.author: gangy86
comments.body: Give a quick check and thats it!

comments.author: MrWolfTX
comments.body: EVERY...SINGLE...TIME...    Bags don't cone in the room until I check.

comments.author: kummer5peck
comments.body: Every time. A quick inspection could prevent any unwanted passengers from coming back with you. You should take other preventative measures such as storing your bags somewhere where they are unlikely to come into contact with any bugs. I also put my bags in the bathtub overnight when I get home. If there are any in there they will try to get out but will get stuck in the tub. They cannot climb porcelain.

comments.author: smartgirl410
comments.body: Absolutely!

comments.author: Cacorm
comments.body: No but I should

comments.author: Fancy-Crown-1409
comments.body: Never checked. Never had an issue (knocks on wood). I'm not even sure what I'll do if I checked and found them since my hotel booking is usually done by a 3rd party for work. They usually book really great and upscale hotels, though.

comments.author: Ms-Unhelpful
comments.body: I always check the crevices of the mattress, and I keep my backpack as far away from the bed and other furniture as possible, usually on the bathroom counter or hanging from a towel hook.

comments.author: Beneficial-Lion-5660
comments.body: If you ever hear someone who works at the front desk say “ baseballs or blueberries” that is industry code for bed bugs. I traveled 100-120 days a year for 20 years.

comments.author: papisilla
comments.body: Yes every single hotel. I didn't used to until I was sharing one with my sister and she had one crawl on her. Now I check every hotel. Usually I'll ask the front desk if I can checkout the room before checking in. Most places don't give you a hard time about it but I almost never reserve rooms online

comments.author: Glum-Astronomer2989
comments.body: Yes, yes, 1000% yes. If I found out I afterwards that I had stayed in an infested room I would trash all my clothes and luggage as well.

comments.author: 359dawson
comments.body: Holy hell-brought bb back from the Williamsburg lodge. My son still has trauma from it. We had to heat treat our entire house just so he would sleep in his room again. Please check your hotel room.

comments.author: MajorIllustrious5082
comments.body: Never thought too. I travel a lot for work too but only stay in 5 star hotels where i would expect the beds to be changed every couple days.

comments.author: HookerInAYellowDress
comments.body: Absolutely not. My kids are jumping on the beds with their shoes on before I can even put down my purse. Who has time for that???

comments.author: lets_get_wavy_duuude
comments.body:

comments.author: pocahantaswarren
comments.body:
Had to hire exterminators. Luckily it wasn’t a full blown disgusting infestation like my neighbors unit where they were literally everywhere — all over the walls, etc. Disgusting. 

They sprayed stuff around my floor, sprinkled some sort of powder, and then I had to wash and dry all my clothes on hot water and high heat. And had to put all my belongings in black trash bags and leave them outside in the AZ sun. It did the trick but it was a horrendous 6 months trying to get rid of them. One day I got home and took my shorts off to shower and when I finished I saw a bedbug crawling on my shorts. Just absolutely traumatic not knowing if you have one in your clothes or in your backpack, etc. Makes it real hard to ever relax and your home becomes anything but a safe haven. Hence my psychological scars and my absolute policy on always checking.

comments.author: Ok-Wafer-3258
comments.body:
Heat is the only thing that kill bedbugs in all states (eggs -> adults) of their life. 

So putting everything into a sauna or dryer at the highest safe level of your clothes and let them bake. 

At 45°C core temperature they will die within an hour. So pushing it even further  (+60°C) will make it safer  and faster.
